question: Question_01_(a)
statement:
Suppose you are given a set of \emph{N} data points
\emph{(x\textsubscript{n}, y\textsubscript{n})}, with
\emph{x\textsubscript{n}} increasing, and you wish to interpolate these
points with a spline function \emph{$f$}, where \emph{$f$(x)} is given by
the cubic polynomial \emph{p\textsubscript{n}(x)} on each interval
\emph{(x\textsubscript{n}, x\textsubscript{n+1})} for \emph{n = 1, ...,
N-1}:

\[\displaystyle
p_n(x) = a_n(x-x_n)^3 + b_n(x-x_n)^2 + c_n(x-x_n) + d_n\]

\textbf{(a)} Write down the equations required for \emph{$f$(x)} to be
continuous and to pass through the data points. How many equations does
this provide?
sols:
For \emph{$f$(x)} to pass through all the data points, we must have
\emph{p\textsubscript{n}(x\textsubscript{n}) = y\textsubscript{n}} and
for \emph{$f$(x)} to be continuous, we must have
\emph{p\textsubscript{n}(x\textsubscript{n+1}) = y\textsubscript{n+1}}.
Each of these give us \emph{N-1} equations because there are \emph{N-1}
polynomials. So in total, \emph{(N-1) + (N-1) = 2N - 2} equations.
